what do you mean?
your computer is using the ext3 filesystem. ext2 is an older version of it. those undeletion tools won't work on ext3 for all i know
how do you know that my computer is an ext2 filesystem?
ext3, not ext2. i know because every ubuntu uses ext3 by default
the answer is, as far as i know, *no tool*. no way to recover the files. others might have better advice, but i never heard anything different about this
really?
if you removed them from the shell, it logs that in your .bash_history, inside your home dir
so the system doesn't log deleted files?
no, it doesn't
why not?
if you actually remove them by typing "rm", that is logged so
best you can do, i think, is    cat /dev/hda | grep -A 100 -B 100 "some-text-string-that-was-in-your-files" >recovered
you might get some bits and pieces of your files into the "recover" file. you can't really do anything better
